If you create a second bindle, if your bindle is more than 1 mile away from you, or when you die, the bindle loses its magic, and anything inside appears in unoccupied spaces closest to the container.

entries.name: Whistled Spells
entries: You can whistle in place of Verbal components for your Bard spells. Observers unfamiliar with this tradition must succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check to recognize your spellcasting for what it is by whistled Verbal components alone.

subclassFeature.name: Homeward Bound
entries: You can whistle to conjure a ghostly train that returns you and your companions to a known destination. When you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can leave a mark at that location using paint, chalk, carving, or some other medium (which can be erased, defaced, or destroyed normally).

Thereafter, you can use this feature to cast {@spell Teleportation Circle|XPHB} using the mark as the destination. When you cast the spell in this way, a phantom train whisks away creatures who enter the circle, and you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can have a number of marked locations equal to your Charisma modifier at one time (minimum of 1 location). If you mark a location beyond your maximum, one of the previous marks of your choice fades.
When you reach level 9 in this class, you always have {@spell Teleportation Circle|XPHB} prepared and can use any of your marked locations as the destination when you cast it.

subclassFeature.name: Ride the Rails
entries: You can whistle as a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to summon a spectral locomotive into existence. It hurtles forward in a 120-foot-long, 10-foot-wide {@variantrule Line [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Line} from you, and it passes through objects and creatures.

You and up to six willing creatures of your choice within 30 feet of you can hitch a ride on the train. You teleport to an unoccupied space of your choice in the {@variantrule Line [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Line}, and any creatures who accompanied you appear in the closest unoccupied spaces to you.

Each other creature in the {@variantrule Line [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Line} must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or have the {@condition Deafened|XPHB} condition until the start of your next turn, be pushed up to 10 feet straight away from the {@variantrule Line [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Line}'s point of origin, and takes an amount of Psychic damage equal to three rolls of your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|XPHB|1} die.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} unless you expend a spell slot of level 3+ (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Last Stop
entries: The ghostly shrill of your whistle now draws the living closer to the world of the dead. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you blow a whistle that is audible up to 300 feet away. Up to six creatures of your choice that you can see within that range must succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC or be cursed. When a cursed target takes Psychic damage, it has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition toward the source of that damage until the end of its next turn. The first time a cursed target takes Psychic damage, it has {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB} to Psychic damage. The target repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. After 1 minute, it succeeds automatically.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} unless you expend a spell slot of level 7+ (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Harvest Domain
entries: {@i Sow, Grow, and Reap in the Harvest Cycle}

The Harvest Domain draws from the cycle beginning with creation, reaching abundance, and ending in culling before repeating endlessly. Deities of farming and crops can focus on one of the harvest's aspects, but most draw from each phase of the cycle. Clerics of this domain are drawn to the cyclical nature of existence, and they often take on roles as shepherds of different cycles.
Use the Harvest Rites table for inspiration on observances based on each aspect of the harvest cycle.

entries.caption: Harvest Rites
rows: Bury a sacrificial offering into a newly ploughed field, such as dried corn husks, dead fish, robin's egg, or hare's foot
Brew blessed mixtures and concoctions for consumption or irrigation that increase the fertility of crops, livestock, or people
Gift a pouch of seeds to travelers at the start of a journey to ensure they arrive at their destination
Tend to the sick or injured with natural remedies that utilize pure water, fertile soil, rich ash, or fruit poultice to speed up healing
Bless crops or livestock to usher in favorable weather and a growing season that produces a strong and healthy bounty
Oversee marriages, binding the betrothed with woven grain stalks or linen cords
Give funeral rites that return the deceased's body or ashes to the fields, mixing in earth from their home and decaying crops to enrich the soil
Sharpen blades blessed by the harvest gods ahead of a battle or before a harvest to ensure that all that is reaped is offered to the divine
Slaughter adult livestock or reap ripe crops for a feast to celebrate nature's bounty

subclassFeature.name: Community Almanac
entries: You gain an {@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB}, and you have proficiency with it. You also gain proficiency in the {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} skill.

subclassFeature.name: Harvest Domain Spells
entries: Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, choose an aspect of the harvest cycle: Sowing, Growing, or Reaping. Consult the Harvest Domain Spells table; you have the spells listed in the column of your chosen aspect for your Cleric level and lower prepared.

entries.caption: Harvest Domain Spells
rows: 3rd
{@spell Druidcraft|XPHB}, {@spell Goodberry|XPHB}, {@spell Lesser Restoration|XPHB}
{@spell Guidance|XPHB}, {@spell Entangle|XPHB}, {@spell Summer Winds|CrookedMoon24}
{@spell Chill Touch|XPHB}, {@spell Inflict Wounds|XPHB}, {@spell Hold Person|XPHB}
5th
{@spell Harvest Moonglow|CrookedMoon24}
{@spell Plant Growth|XPHB}
{@spell Culling Sickle|CrookedMoon24}
7th
{@spell Death Ward|XPHB}
{@spell Sanctum of the Shepherd|CrookedMoon24}
{@spell Consuming Pyre|CrookedMoon24}
9th
{@spell Awaken|XPHB}
{@spell Mass Cure Wounds|XPHB}
{@spell Field of Reaping|CrookedMoon24}

subclassFeature.name: Cornucopia
entries: If you don't have the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition when you start a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, you can magically create a cornucopia filled with enough food for a number of creatures equal to twice your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. When creatures that eat the food finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, you can distribute a number of d4s equal to your Cleric level among creatures who ate the food. Each creature immediately rolls the dice they're allotted and regains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the total. The cornucopia and any uneaten food vanish when the {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB} ends.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Bountiful Harvest
entries: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you present your {@item Holy Symbol|XPHB} and expend a use of your {@classFeature Channel Divinity|Cleric|XPHB|2} to invoke the spirit of the harvest. Up to six creatures of your choice within 60 feet of you gain {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB}. A creature must finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} before it can gain {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB} from this feature again.
Additionally, you grant all targets one of the following benefits. If your current harvest aspect is a different one, it changes to match the choice.

entries.name: Sowing
entries: A target gains a number of {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} plus your Wisdom modifier.

entries.name: Growing
entries: Until the end of your next turn, when a target makes an attack roll or ability check, it adds {@dice 1d4} to the total.

entries.name: Reaping
entries: A target deals extra Necrotic damage equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} the first time it damages a creature before the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Blessing of the Seasons
entries: You can draw upon the powers of the harvest cycle to potentially avert disaster. When a creature you can see within 30 feet of you fails a saving throw of a particular type determined by your current aspect, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to allow it to reroll the {@dice d20} and use the new roll. The type of saving throws you can affect are as follows.

entries.name: Sowing
entries: Dexterity and Charisma

entries.name: Growing
entries: Constitution and Intelligence

entries.name: Reaping
entries: Wisdom and Strength

Additionally, after the saving throw succeeds or fails, roll a number of d4s equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. The target regains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the total rolled.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Eternal Wheel
entries: When you use your {@subclassFeature Bountiful Harvest|Cleric|XPHB|Harvest|CrookedMoon24|3|CrookedMoon24}, you can invoke the endless cycle of life, death, and rebirth to grant yourself and the creatures affected by your {@classFeature Channel Divinity|Cleric|XPHB|2} an additional benefit based on your current aspect:

entries.name: Sowing
entries: Targets gain the effects of the {@spell Regenerate|XPHB} spell for 1 minute, or until you lose {@status Concentration|XPHB}.

entries.name: Growing
entries: Targets gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws and ability checks for up to 1 hour, or until you lose {@status Concentration|XPHB} (as if {@status Concentration|XPHB|Concentrating} on a spell).

entries.name: Reaping
entries: Targets gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Necrotic, Psychic, and Poison damage for 1 hour.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} unless you expend a spell slot of level 7+ (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Experiment
entries: {@i Augment the Body with Volatile Serums}

Barbarians following the Path of the Experiment supplement their rage with alchemical cocktails that surge in their bodies through syringes and tubes of copper, steel, and glass. These formulas enhance their ability to channel primal might, or perhaps—because of their rage—they are the only people who can survive the chemicals flooding their veins. A Barbarian may have created the implants and serums through their own experimentation, or they could have been subjected to the insidious work of others. Whatever the origin, it could have been well-intentioned and made to enhance or preserve the Barbarian's life, or it might have been an unhinged alchemical exploration.
The Experimental Implants table offers examples of different forms your implants can take.

entries.caption: Experimental Implants
rows: Alchemical Injector. Glass reservoir cylinders set in brass and iron frames hold multicolored, bubbling, or luminous alchemical fluids.

Alien Grafts. Portions of your body have been replaced with parts of a dragon, a werewolf, or an Aberration's rubbery tentacles. When you {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian||1}, the grafts overtake more of your body.
Construct Prosthesis. You have prosthetic limbs, eyes, or other replacements made of metal, stone, or wood. When you {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian||1}, the parts flare.
Crystal Formations. Crystals grow from your body across your shoulders and down your limbs. When you {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian||1}, the crystals glow, chime, or ring.

Fungal Inoculation. Mushrooms and other fungal growths overtake parts of your body, and vein-like mycelium run along your skin from them. When you {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian||1}, the veins pulse and writhe.
Sparktech Augmentation. Copper, silver, and brass coils in your back and arms run wires along your skin to plugs. When you {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian||1}, lightning crackles across the metal.

subclassFeature.name: Alchemical Experiments
entries: You gain a set of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|PHB}, and you have proficiency with it. Additionally, you can use {@item Alchemist's Supplies|PHB} instead of an {@item Herbalism Kit|PHB} to craft {@item Potion of Healing (*)|DMG}.

subclassFeature.name: Volatile Serum
entries: You have an implanted series of syringes and reservoirs that hold alchemical serums and deploy them into your body. When you enter your {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian||1}, choose one of your serums to inject and gain its benefits.
The chosen serum lasts for the duration of your {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian||1}, or until you choose a new serum as a bonus action. You have the following serum options.

entries.name: Ferocity
entries: This serum throws you into an energized frenzy. You ignore {@quickref difficult terrain||3}, and when you hit with a Melee weapon or unarmed strike, you can make another attack with it against a second creature within 5 feet of the first that is also within your reach. On a hit, the second creature takes the weapon's damage, but don't add your ability modifier to that damage unless that modifier is negative. You can make this extra attack only once per turn.

entries.name: Monstrosity
entries: The serum expands your body to monstrous proportions and can change your appearance in cosmetic ways, such as by altering facial features, skin tone, and hair length or color. Your reach increases by 5 feet, and once per turn when you miss with an attack roll that relies on Strength, you can add your rage damage bonus to the total, potentially causing the attack to hit. If you are smaller than Large, you become Large, along with anything you are wearing or carrying. If there isn't enough room to accommodate the size change, your size doesn't change.

entries.name: Reconstruction
entries: The serum dulls pain and forces wounds to rapidly knit. Upon activation and at the start of each of your turns, you can expend and roll a Hit Die. You regain a number of hit points equal to the number rolled plus your Constitution modifier (minimum of 1 hit point). You gain any excess beyond your hit point maximum as temporary hit points. If you take acid or fire damage, this serum doesn't function at the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Augmentation Compounds
entries: Through continued experimentation or your natural adaptation to your implants, you can now activate one of the compound options below, in addition to a serum, when you enter your {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian||1} or change your chosen serum. The chosen compound lasts for the duration of your {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian||1}, or until you choose a new compound.

entries.name: Stimulated Senses
entries: You gain {@sense blindsight} out to a range of 30 feet. If you already have {@sense blindsight}, its range increases by 30 feet.

entries.name: Maddening Fumes
entries: Your skin emits aggression-spiking fumes out to 30 feet. While in that area, an enemy's speed is halved, and if it starts its turn there, it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC 8 plus your Constitution modifier and proficiency bonus) or have disadvantage on attack rolls against targets other than you until the start of its next turn.

entries.name: Corrosive Expulsion
entries: When you take the {@action Attack|PHB} action on your turn, you can replace one of your attacks with a spray of caustic chemicals from your implants in a 15-foot cone, or a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide (choose the shape each time). Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw (DC 8 plus your Constitution modifier and proficiency bonus). Roll a number of d8s equal to your rage damage bonus. On a failed save, a target takes acid damage equal to the total rolled, or half as much damage on a successful one.

subclassFeature.name: Reactive Catalyst
entries: Your implants are now sensitive to your response to danger and flood you with stimulating chemicals. When you take damage, or when you are {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition poisoned}, or {@condition stunned}, you can use your reaction to enter your rage before the damage or conditions are applied. When you enter your rage, you end any of those conditions on yourself, including any triggering conditions.
Additionally, while your rage is active, you have advantage on Constitution saving throws.

subclassFeature.name: Biochemical Admixture
entries: Your body focuses and combines the strength of your serums. When you activate an option of your {@subclassFeature Volatile Serum|Barbarian|PHB|Experiment|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14}, you activate two options instead of one. Additionally, when a creature within 5 feet of you damages you with a melee attack while your rage is active, the creature takes {@damage 1d12} acid damage. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: College of Whistles
entries: {@i Wander with Wayward Spirits}

Old tales speak of the dangers of whistling: the hollow, haunting pitches call to the spirits of the departed and invite them back to the world of the living. Bards of the College of Whistles take these stories and set them to their own warbling tunes, whistling forth their bardic magic and summoning spirits to aid in their travels. These Bards wander even more than most of their fellows, drawn to traveling and gathering both stories and ghosts like patches in tattered clothing.

The Wandering Visits table offers suggestions on places you've visited during your travels where you met the various spirits drawn to your whistles. You can use the examples as they're given, mix and match the locations and the spirits, or create your own.

entries.caption: Wandering Visits
rows: You found an abandoned tavern with a single place still set at a table in the corner. A melancholy spirit waited there for someone who would never arrive.
Scorched foundations are the only remains of a cottage that burned long ago. The echo of a singing child watched over travelers who stopped there.
You stayed in a manor house's haunted tower quarters. The angry spirit there is the remnant of someone who died, old and infirm—helpless to stop the wickedness they saw from afar.
The mournful song of a lingering soul drew you to an old, covered bridge—the only place where the spirit found hope in life.
An orphanage with a positive reputation housed the hopeful shade of a child who died of sickness. It was a companion to other orphans until they grew or were taken in by homes.
A misty roadside meadow was once the site of a terrible battle. The spirit of a soldier who died there vented its fury against con artists and bandits who preyed upon the roadway.

subclassFeature.name: Handy Haints
entries: You can call forth haints—vagabond spirits. When you inspire a creature with {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|PHB|1}, you can summon a ghostly apparition that drifts around the inspired target.

The haint creates an aura extending 15 feet from the target. The haint vanishes after 1 minute, when you summon a new haint, when you use the reaction it grants you, or if you are {@condition incapacitated} or die. When you summon a haint, choose its form: Grump, Sad Sack, or Scamp.

entries.name: Grump
entries: This red-tinged, elderly spirit dressed in threadbare rags threatens your foes and harangues your allies to do better. The inspired creature and its allies within the aura have advantage on Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks and Strength saving throws. In addition, when a creature inside the aura deals damage, you can use your reaction to increase the damage dealt to one target by a roll of your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|PHB|1} die plus your Charisma modifier.

entries.name: Sad Sack
entries: The blueish, melancholic spirit saps the fervor from your foes. The inspired creature and its allies within the aura have {@quickref Cover||3||half cover} against ranged attacks. In addition, when a creature inside the aura takes damage, you can use your reaction to reduce the damage taken by an amount equal to a roll of your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|PHB|1} die plus your Charisma modifier.

entries.name: Scamp
entries: The gold-hued, childlike spirit delights and invigorates your allies. When the inspired creature or its allies starts a turn in the aura, that creature's speed increases by 10 feet until the end of its next turn. In addition, when a creature inside the aura fails a saving throw, you can use your reaction to let the creature reroll the {@dice d20}.

subclassFeature.name: Whistling Wanderer
entries: You've shaped the superstition of whistling to the dead into a potent instrument. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Wanderer's Bindle
entries: When you finish a long rest, you can touch a nonmagical bag, sack, or similar container and turn it into a magical container called a bindle. This container functions as a {@item Heward's Handy Haversack|DMG|Handy Haversack}. If you create a second bindle, if your bindle is more than 1 mile away from you, or when you die, the bindle loses its magic, and anything inside appears in unoccupied spaces closest to the container.

entries.name: Whistled Spells
entries: You can whistle in place of verbal components for your bard spells. Observers unfamiliar with this tradition must succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check to recognize your spellcasting for what it is by whistled verbal components alone.

subclassFeature.name: Homeward Bound
entries: You can whistle to conjure a ghostly train that returns you and your companions to a known destination. When you finish a long rest, you can leave a mark at that location using paint, chalk, carving, or some other medium (which can be erased, defaced, or destroyed normally).

Thereafter, you can use this feature to cast {@spell Teleportation Circle} using the mark as the destination. When you cast the spell in this way, a phantom train whisks away creatures who enter the circle, and you can't cast it again until you finish a long rest. You can have a number of marked locations equal to your Charisma modifier at one time (minimum of 1 location). If you mark a location beyond your maximum, one of the previous marks of your choice fades.
When you reach 9th level in this class, you always have Teleportation Circle prepared and can use any of your marked locations as the destination when you cast it.

subclassFeature.name: Ride the Rails
entries: You can whistle as an action to summon a spectral locomotive into existence. It hurtles forward in a 120-foot-long, 10-foot-wide line from you, and it passes through objects and creatures.

You and up to six willing creatures of your choice within 30 feet of you can hitch a ride on the train. You teleport to an unoccupied space of your choice in the line, and any creatures who accompanied you appear in the closest unoccupied spaces to you.

Each other creature in the line must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or be {@condition deafened} until the start of your next turn, be pushed up to 10 feet straight away from the line's point of origin, and take an amount of psychic damage equal to three rolls of your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|PHB|1} die.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest unless you expend a spell slot of 3rd level or higher (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Last Stop
entries: The ghostly shrill of your whistle now draws the living closer to the world of the dead. As an action, you blow a whistle that is audible up to 300 feet away. Up to six creatures of your choice that you can see within that range must succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC or be cursed for 1 minute. When a cursed target takes psychic damage, it is {@condition frightened} of the source of that damage until the end of its next turn. The first time a cursed target takes psychic damage, it has vulnerability to psychic damage. The target repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest unless you expend a spell slot of 7th level or higher (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Wicker
entries: {@i Craft Effigies of Sacrifice and Protection}

Cunning in their ancient art, Druids of the Circle of Wicker fashion twig dolls and effigies, binding their magic into these crude forms. These creations often resemble animals, rune shapes, natural symbols, or people. Protective tokens and promises of retribution against trespassers are these Druids' stock in trade. You can weave the magic of the land through your wicker creations as boons to your friends and banes to your foes.

The effigies, charms, and tokens you weave can take a variety of shapes, each intending a ritualistic effect. Use the Wicker Effigies table for inspiration when determining your wicker token's appearance.

entries.caption: Wicker Effigies
rows: Antlered bowman to ensure a successful hunt
Bird-headed scarecrow to protect crops from pests and blight
Apple-adorned fertility goddess for a bountiful harvest
Unsettling stick figures to ward off interlopers from hidden dwellings
Goat with curved horns to ensure a safe winter
Wolf's head to protect against dangers of the night
Crescent moon with a crone's face to amplify magic rituals
Fearsome tusked mask to grant ferocity in battle
Spiraled sunburst with a grin to herald a long, warm summer
Three-sided pyramid with laddered edges to mark the site of a sacrifice
Club-wielding troll to guard roads, bridges, and other passageways
Intricate ring that represents the cycle of the year to guarantee life, death, and rebirth

subclassFeature.name: Bewitched Effigy
entries: Your primal magic can manifest as a wicker effigy and radiate out from it. As a bonus action, you can expend a use of your Wild Shape to create a wicker effigy in an unoccupied space you can see within 30 feet of yourself.

The effigy is a Small object (AC 15; HP equal to five times your druid level; vulnerability to fire damage; immunity to poison and psychic damage). The effigy vanishes after 1 minute, when reduced to 0 hit points, or when you use this feature again. It creates one of the following auras (chosen when you create the effigy) in a 30-foot radius that is filled with {@quickref Vision and Light||2||dim light}.

entries.name: Sacrifice
entries: When a creature in the aura takes damage, you can use your reaction to deal fire damage to the creature equal to {@dice 1d8} plus your Wisdom modifier.

entries.name: Soothe
entries: When you create the effigy, and as a bonus action on subsequent turns while the effigy remains, one creature that you can see within the aura regains {@dice 1d6} hit points. You can use this effigy to restore hit points a number of times equal to twice your spellcasting ability modifier.

entries.name: Ward
entries: You and your allies within the aura gain a +1 bonus to AC.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Wicker Spells
entries: When you reach a druid level specified in the Circle of Wicker Spells table, you always have the spells prepared, and they don't count against the number spells you can prepare each day. These spells are druid spells for you.

entries.caption: Circle of Wicker Spells
rows: 2nd
{@spell Bane|PHB}, {@spell Bless|PHB}
3rd
{@spell Summer Winds|CrookedMoon14}, {@spell Zone of Truth|PHB}
5th
{@spell Bestow Curse|PHB}, {@spell Leomund's Tiny Hut|PHB|Tiny Hut}
7th
{@spell Death Ward|PHB}, {@spell Sanctum of the Shepherd|CrookedMoon14}
9th
{@spell Hold Monster|PHB}, {@spell Lucky Charm|CrookedMoon14}

subclassFeature.name: Wicker Token
entries: You can weave wicker tokens that carry a touch of your magic. When you finish a long rest, you can create a number of tokens equal to your proficiency bonus. The tokens are Tiny objects (AC 5; HP 1; immunity to poison and psychic damage). The tokens vanish when you finish your next long rest.
You can cast spells with a range of touch on a creature carrying one of your tokens while the two of you are on the same plane of existence.

subclassFeature.name: Wicker Rising
entries: The energy you channel through your wicker effigy grows stronger, empowering its benefits.

entries.name: Sacrifice
entries: The fire damage increases to {@dice 2d8} plus your Wisdom modifier.

entries.name: Soothe
entries: The healing of your effigy increases to {@dice 1d8}, and when you target a creature with the effigy, you can expend 5 hit points from the effigy to remove one of the following conditions on the target: {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition poisoned}, {@condition stunned}.

entries.name: Ward
entries: Choose a damage type other than force. You and your allies in the aura have resistance to the chosen type.

subclassFeature.name: Soulbound Poppet
entries: As an action, you can expend a use of your Wild Shape and choose a creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself to magically create a wicker doll that vaguely resembles the target. The doll is a Tiny object (AC 10; HP 10; vulnerability to fire damage; immunity to poison and psychic damage). The doll vanishes after 1 minute or when it is reduced to 0 hit points. While the doll exists, the target has disadvantage on attack rolls against a creature carrying the doll, and when a creature carrying the doll damages the target for the first time on a turn, the target takes an extra {@damage 2d10} necrotic damage.

subclassFeature.name: Wicker Zenith
entries: Your wicker effigies reach the pinnacle of their power. At the start of your turn, you can change your effigy's aura to a different one. Additionally, all the auras grow stronger in the following ways.

entries.name: Sacrifice
entries: The fire damage increases to {@dice 3d8} plus your Wisdom modifier.

entries.name: Soothe
entries: When you or your allies start a turn in the aura, the {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} condition (target's choice) ends on it.

entries.name: Ward
entries: Choose an ability. You and each of your allies within the aura have advantage on saving throws made with the chosen ability.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Old Ways
entries: {@i Become One with the Ancient Forest}

Favoring the heart of the darkest forests, Druids of the Circle of the Old Ways commune with ancient, forgotten entities that lurk within, calling forth truly primeval power to serve as defenders of the oldest and wildest of places.
They harness the power of the Elderwood trees, which are home to the souls of long-dead feyfolk and share their primordial wisdom and might when called upon.

The Old Ways Sacred Sites table offers examples to choose or use as inspiration to create places steeped in the Old Ways where your circle might congregate or where you may commune with primeval powers.

entries.caption: Old Ways Sacred Sites
rows: Ring of standing stones atop a remote hilltop, each one marked with runes and symbols representing animal spirits
Perpetually frozen river at the bottom of a deep ravine with a plethora of oversized and seemingly intelligent fish beneath the ice
Hidden cave buried beneath a scorched dune, revealed by the shifting sands for a single night four times a year
Turbulent tidepool by the coast with bottomless waters filled with glowing flora, fauna, and crystalline outcroppings
Circle of ancient trees with ghost-white bark and blood-red leaves, each one bearing the face of a long-dead druid
Massive barrow in the deep woods which contains the spirits of countless fey folk and the old gods of the natural world

entries.subclassFeature: Circle of the Old Ways Spells|Druid|PHB|Old Ways|CrookedMoon14|2

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Old Ways Spells
entries: You learn the {@spell Shillelagh} cantrip if you don't know it already, and your study of the Old Ways gives you access to certain spells as listed in the Circle of the Old Ways Spells table for your level and lower. You always have the spells prepared, and they don't count against the number spells you can prepare each day. These spells are druid spells for you.

entries.caption: Circle of the Old Ways Spells
rows: 2nd
{@spell Ancestral Communion|CrookedMoon14}, {@spell Shield of Faith|PHB}, {@spell Shillelagh|PHB}
3rd
{@spell Barkskin|PHB}, {@spell Spike Growth|PHB}
5th
{@spell Magic Circle|PHB}, {@spell Plant Growth|PHB}
7th
{@spell Freedom of Movement|PHB}, {@spell Mordenkainen's Private Sanctum|PHB|Private Sanctum}
9th
{@spell Awaken|PHB}, {@spell Tree Stride|PHB}

subclassFeature.name: Bough and Branch
entries: Even the humblest of your weapons channels the might of the old forest. When you cast {@spell Shillelagh}, you can cause a shield made of gnarled wood to grow into your free hand if you have one (no action required to don it), and it vanishes when the spell ends. You can't be forced to drop the affected weapon or shield unless you are {@condition incapacitated}. Additionally, for the duration of the spell, you ignore somatic components of your druid spells, and the weapon enhanced by the spell becomes a {@item druidic focus} for you.

subclassFeature.name: Wood Wose
entries: As a bonus action, or as part of casting {@spell Shillelagh|phb}, you can expend a use of your Wild Shape to suffuse yourself with the power of the primordial woods, gaining the following benefits.

entries.name: Bark Bulwark
entries: While you aren't wearing armor, your base Armor Class is 10 plus your Dexterity and Wisdom modifiers.

entries.name: Elderwood Sap
entries: When you hit a creature with an attack roll using the weapon enhanced by {@spell Shillelagh|phb}, the target is coated in Elderwood sap until the start of your next turn. While coated, the target has disadvantage on attack rolls against targets other than you.

entries.name: Oaken Resolve
entries: You have advantage on Strength and Constitution saving throws.
This effect lasts for 10 minutes. It ends early if you dismiss it (no action required), are {@condition incapacitated}, or die.

subclassFeature.name: Oak and Thorn
entries: The wrath of the Elderwoods drives you and punishes your foes. When you activate your {@subclassFeature Wood Wose|Druid|PHB|Old Ways|CrookedMoon14|2|CrookedMoon14}, you gain the following additional benefits for the duration.

entries.name: Oakenfist
entries: You can attack twice instead of once whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

entries.name: Gnarled Thorns
entries: Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a melee attack roll using a weapon, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d6} piercing damage.

subclassFeature.name: Deepwood Elder
entries: Your connection to the Elderwood grows stronger. When you activate your {@subclassFeature Wood Wose|Druid|PHB|Old Ways|CrookedMoon14|2|CrookedMoon14}, you now gain additional benefits for the duration.

entries.name: Primeval Wrath
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a creature with a melee attack, you can force the target to succeed on a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC or be knocked {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Bramblebark
entries: When a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, the attacker takes {@damage 1d8} piercing damage. A creature takes this damage only once per turn.

entries.name: Rampant Growth
entries: When you activate {@subclassFeature Wood Wose|Druid|PHB|Old Ways|CrookedMoon14|2|CrookedMoon14} and at the start of each of your subsequent turns, you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to your Wisdom modifier plus your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Ancient Protector
entries: When you awaken your connection to the Elderwood, you now become an incarnation of its ancient might. When you activate your {@subclassFeature Wood Wose|Druid|PHB|Old Ways|CrookedMoon14|2|CrookedMoon14}, you now gain additional benefits for the duration.

entries.name: Old Growth
entries: Your size increases to Large (along with anything you're wearing or carrying) if there is space to accommodate your growth, and your reach increases by 5 feet.

entries.name: Mighty Trunk
entries: You gain resistance to bludgeoning and piercing damage.

entries.name: Vengeance of the Elders
entries: When a creature that is covered in Elderwood Sap and is within your reach makes an attack roll, you can use your reaction to make a melee attack against that creature.

subclassFeature.name: Barrow Guard
entries: {@i Command the Might of the Grave}

Barrow Guards are warriors who harness the power of the dead, taking upon themselves spectral energies normally forbidden to the living. Some Barrow Guards are those returned from the dead through magical miracles or the whims of the gods. Others stand at the doors of sacred crypts, ready to push back any who attempt to desecrate the dead. No matter their origin, these stoic sentinels are unconcerned with matters of the living. They are separate, other, and duty-bound to their role as crypt-keepers, ensuring the dead—heroes and villains alike—remain at rest.

subclassFeature.name: Death Knight
entries: You house within you the lingering remnants of souls long-departed, and their knowledge and experience imbue you with necromantic energy. It is represented by Draugr Dice, which fuel powers you have from this subclass. The Barrow Guard Draugr Dice table shows the die size and number of these dice you have when you reach certain fighter levels.

entries.caption: Barrow Guard Draugr Dice
rows: 3rd
{@dice D6}
5th
{@dice D8}
9th
{@dice D8}
11th
{@dice D10}
13th
{@dice D10}
17th
{@dice D12}

entries: Some of your powers expend a Draugr Die, as specified in a feature's description, and you can't use a power if it requires you to use a die when all your Draugr Dice are expended.
You regain one expended Draugr Die when you finish a short rest, and you regain all of them when you finish a long rest.
The save DC for any of your powers is 8 plus your Constitution modifier and proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Dark Rider
entries: As a bonus action, you manifest a ghostly steed that only you can mount. The steed uses the Warhorse stat block, but its creature type is Undead, it has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage, and it can only take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, and {@action Dodge} actions. When the steed takes the {@action Dash} action, you can expend and roll a Draugr Die. During the movement from that action, the steed's speed increases by a number of feet equal to 5 times the number rolled. The steed vanishes after 1 hour, if reduced to 0 hit points, if you are {@condition incapacitated}, or if you die.
Once you take this bonus action, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest, unless you expend a Draugr Die (no action required) to restore your use of it.

entries.name: Grave Guard
entries: When you take damage, you can use your reaction to expend and roll a Draugr Die. Reduce the damage you take by the number rolled plus your Constitution modifier.

entries.name: Soul Reaper
entries: When you take the {@action Attack} action, you can forego one of your attacks to magically call forth ghostly hands around a creature within 60 feet of yourself. Expend and roll a Draugr Die. The target must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, it takes necrotic damage equal to the number rolled on the Draugr Die plus your Constitution modifier, and it has the {@condition grappled} condition (escape DC = your Death Knight power save DC) for 1 minute. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage only.

subclassFeature.name: Siphoning Souls
entries: You can capture the fleeing essence of departing souls to glean knowledge and prowess. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Mortal Coil
entries: When an enemy that isn't a Construct or Undead within 30 feet of you dies, you can use your reaction to regain one expended Draugr Die.

entries.name: Whisper of the Departed
entries: When you make an ability check, you can expend and roll a Draugr Die and add the number rolled to the total.

subclassFeature.name: Tomb Castellan
entries: The powers of your Death Knight feature improve in the following ways.

entries.name: Phantom Charger
entries: The ghostly steed of your Dark Rider power now ignores {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|PHB}. Additionally, when your steed takes the {@action Dash|PHB}, {@action Disengage|PHB}, or {@action Dodge|PHB} action, you can expend and roll a Draugr Die. Your steed magically teleports (with you if you're riding it) to an unoccupied space you can see within 60 feet of the steed. Each creature of your choice within 10 feet of the steed when it appears must succeed on a Constitution saving throw, taking Necrotic damage equal to the number rolled on the Draugr Die plus your Constitution modifier on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Death Knell
entries: When you use your Grave Guard power in response to a creature damaging you, the creature takes Psychic damage equal to half the amount of damage the power reduced.

entries.name: Spectral Shrieking
entries: When a creature {@condition Grappled|PHB} by your Soul Reaper power starts its turn, it takes Psychic damage equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|PHB|Proficiency Bonus}. When it does, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|PHB} to expend and roll a Draugr Die, adding the number rolled to the damage.

subclassFeature.name: Grave Lord
entries: You are no longer a mere vessel for spectral energy, but a lord of it. Your powers improve in the following ways.

entries.name: On A Pale Horse
entries: When you use your Dark Rider power, you can allow one creature of your choice to mount the steed in addition to you. Additionally, when you expend a Draugr Die during the steed's {@action Dash} action, it can move through solid objects and creatures as if they were {@quickref difficult terrain||3} (along with any riders). If the steed ends its turn inside a solid object, it and any riders take {@damage 1d10} force damage and are shunted to the nearest unoccupied space.

entries.name: Sepulchral Shield
entries: When you use your Grave Guard power, choose one of the triggering damage types. You have resistance to that damage type (including the triggering damage) until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Death Grip
entries: A creature {@condition grappled} by your Soul Reaper power is {@condition restrained} until the grapple ends.

subclassFeature.name: Might of the Necropolis
entries: Your command of the secrets imparted to you is absolute. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Eternal Vigil
entries: You no longer suffer the effects of aging, you can't be magically aged, and you don't die of old age. In addition, you no longer require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Restless Dead
entries: When you roll initiative, if you have fewer than 3 Draugr Dice, you regain expended dice until you have 3.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Pestilent Haze
entries: {@i Spread Virulent Plague with a Touch}

Warriors of the Pestilent Haze draw plague into their very beings, folding it into their energy and becoming one with the disease. Monks who follow this tradition wander, often following or even preceding waves of pestilence. Some walk with caution, their touch measured, unleashing sickness only where dense populations must be culled. Others revel in the miasma spreading as far and fast as possible.

Your Miasmic Plague is a unique magical contagion that can take many forms that you weave through your deep connection to the affliction. The Plague Manifestations table offers suggestions for what magical form your signature disease takes as it spreads, as well as its hallmark symptoms.

entries.caption: Plague Manifestations
rows: {@b Bloodbreath.} Bruise-colored miasma, the edges of which form into slithering tentacles—painful bruises and a hoarse, bloody cough
{@b Drone Spew.} Swarm of monstrous, mutated flies that buzz with a horrifying drone—bleeding ears and intense vomiting
{@b Festergut.} Viscous, gray sewer water that leaves a film on surfaces—intense stomach pain, dehydration, and blood loss
{@b Gutterpox.} Globs of toxic, greenish sludge that oozes erratically to the touch—swollen, green papules and oppressive mucus buildup
{@b Knell Fever.} Hot wind that prickles the skin and howls with the sound of a tolling bell—heat blisters and feverish hallucinations
{@b Rotface.} Numerous spiked, fungal spores that float through the air—rapid rotting of flesh, especially around the eyes and mouth
{@b The Unclean.} Undulating mass of pallid flesh, teeth, and tongues—grotesque, mutated growths such as new tentacle-like appendages and gnashing mouths
{@b Toadscale.} Infected rains filled with venomous, spectral toads—hardened, itchy patches of scaly skin that turn vibrantly colorful and fits of agonized croaking
{@b Verminplague.} Scurrying mass of ravenous, spectral plague rats that gnaw and scratch victims—painful boils and pustules and an incessant, squeaking cough
{@b Yellow Death.} Billowing, skull-shaped clouds of foul-smelling fumes with a sickly yellow hue—debilitating fatigue, muscle aches, and sunken, sallow skin

subclassFeature.name: Contagious Discipline
entries: You have brewed and concentrated disease within yourself and can now push manifestations of it outward. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Claws of Pestilence
entries: Your nails grow into a set of vermin-like claws. You can deal slashing damage when you hit with an unarmed strike instead of bludgeoning damage. When you hit a creature with an attack granted by your Flurry of Blows, you deal extra necrotic damage equal to one roll of your Martial Arts die.

entries.name: Miasmic Plague
entries: When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can expend 1 ki point to force the creature to succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be cursed for 1 minute. While cursed, the creature has the {@condition poisoned} condition, and it takes extra necrotic damage from your unarmed strikes equal to one roll of your Martial Arts die. A creature can take this damage only once per turn. The creature repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
If you forego the extra damage granted by Claws of Pestilence, you can use Miasmic Plague without paying its ki point cost.

subclassFeature.name: Gift of Pestilence
entries: Through your observation and meditation, you are attuned to the nature of pestilence and the creatures believed to carry it. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Inoculation
entries: You have advantage on saving throws to avoid or end the {@condition poisoned} condition or diseases, and you have resistance to poison and necrotic damage.

entries.name: Vermin Kinship
entries: Through chittering sounds and hand gestures, you can communicate simple concepts to vermin, such as rats, pigeons, and insects, and you gain the ability to decipher their noises and motions. Vermin lack the intelligence to convey or understand sophisticated concepts, but friendly vermin could relay what they have seen or heard in the recent past. Additionally, you can cast {@spell Animal Messenger} using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability targeting a Tiny Beast that is considered vermin and thought to spread plague and disease. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Plague
entries: The strain of your plague becomes more virulent and deadly. When you deal necrotic or poison damage, you ignore the target's resistance to those damage types, if any.

subclassFeature.name: Tolling Censer
entries: You can unleash a cloud of miasma upon your enemies. As an action, you can expend 2 ki points to magically unleash a cloud of miasma in a 20-foot radius around you. Each creature of your choice in that area must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes necrotic damage equal to two rolls of your Martial Arts die and is cursed by your {@subclassFeature Contagious Discipline|Monk|PHB|Pestilent Haze|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14|Miasmic Plague}. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage only.

subclassFeature.name: Miasmic Contagion
entries: The strength of your {@subclassFeature Contagious Discipline|Monk|PHB|Pestilent Haze|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14|Miasmic Plague} has increased, granting you the following benefits.

entries.name: Choking Miasma
entries: Constitution saving throws against your {@subclassFeature Contagious Discipline|Monk|PHB|Pestilent Haze|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14|Miasmic Plague} have disadvantage.

entries.name: Scurrying Spread
entries: When you use your Step of the Wind, until the end of the turn, when you enter a space within 5 feet of any creature of your choice, it must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be cursed by your {@subclassFeature Contagious Discipline|Monk|PHB|Pestilent Haze|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14|Miasmic Plague}. A creature makes this save only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Epidemic
entries: Your plague has reached the height of its potency and its symptoms rapidly afflict your foes. Your {@subclassFeature Contagious Discipline|Monk|PHB|Pestilent Haze|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14|Miasmic Plague} ignores a target's immunity to the {@condition poisoned} condition. Additionally, when you deal necrotic damage to a target cursed by your {@subclassFeature Contagious Discipline|Monk|PHB|Pestilent Haze|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14|Miasmic Plague}, it takes extra necrotic damage equal to one roll of your Martial Arts die.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Castigation
entries: {@i Seek Out and Burn Wickedness to Ash}

Evil and wickedness are widespread and long-lived, but not infinite. Paladins who swear the Oath of Castigation root evil out to burn it away utterly, giving light to all that is innocent and good. Whether bound by the laws of mortals, their deity, or their own personal code, they relentlessly hunt down evil where it thrives. Paladins of this oath know evil cannot hide in any festering place once it burns.

The Wicked Nemeses table offers examples of malefactors, villains, and other evil beings that you have rooted out and purged in the past, or perhaps one you're still hunting. Facing these nemeses may have put you on the path of purging wickedness wherever it lurks.

entries.caption: Wicked Nemeses
rows: A rotting vampire noble who spreads a deadly plague through the command of countless vermin
A brutal contract killer who sells their services to various cults and shadowy organizations
A charismatic cult leader who lords over a remote island, making seasonal sacrifices of mortals to ensure a bountiful harvest each year
An immensely intelligent flesh golem that killed its creator to pursue its own sinister work with strange science and gruesome experiments
A bitterly envious hag of the woods who corrupts the youth of small villages and manipulates them to commit horrific atrocities
A proud and vain heretic who gathers zealous followers after a bloody schism to initiate a brutal crusade in the name of their twisted beliefs
A once-renowned hunter now cursed with lycanthropy who has gone on bloody rampages
A relentless necromancer who scours ancient ruins for forbidden magic to free their otherworldly master from an eldritch prison
A strange amphibious creature that emerges from the depths to kidnap innocents and drag them below the water's surface for unknown purposes
A brilliant doctor who has perfected a serum that transforms them into a hulking brute to commit a string of murders throughout a city
A bloodthirsty revenant who was once a dark knight and now musters other Undead riders to bring about death and decay
A tortured artist bearing a mask of comedy and tragedy who strives for their masterpiece through the mutilation of their victims' corpses

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: You gain the following Channel Divinity options. See the Sacred Oath class feature for how Channel Divinity works.

entries.name: Castigate
entries: As an action, you can use your Channel Divinity to clap those you would bring to justice in fiery shackles. Choose a number of creatures up to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1 creature) you can see within 30 feet of yourself. Each creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be wrapped in fiery shackles and have its speed reduced to 0 for 1 minute. As a bonus action, you can cause the shackles to flare. Each creature bound by the shackles takes {@damage 2d6} fire damage. A shackled creature repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

entries.name: Incite
entries: As an action, you can use your Channel Divinity to better seek out wickedness and corruption. For the next 10 minutes, you have advantage on Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) and Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks.

During that time, you can take a bonus action to choose a creature you can see within 10 feet of you. The target must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. While the target is {@condition frightened} in this way, it can't speak a deliberate lie. The condition ends early if the target takes damage or if you use this bonus action again.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Castigation Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed in the Oath of Castigation Spells table. See the Sacred Oath class feature for how oath spells work.

entries.caption: Oath of Castigation Spells
rows: 3rd
{@spell Divine Favor|PHB}, {@spell Inflict Wounds|PHB}
5th
{@spell Chain of Conviction|CrookedMoon14}, {@spell Hold Person|PHB}
9th
{@spell Counterspell|PHB}, {@spell Speak with Dead|PHB}
13th
{@spell Consuming Pyre|CrookedMoon14}, {@spell Locate Creature|PHB}
17th
{@spell Flame Strike|PHB}, {@spell Hold Monster|PHB}

subclassFeature.name: Kindling Aura
entries: You and your allies within your {@classFeature Aura of Protection|Paladin|PHB|6} ignore creatures' resistance to fire and radiant damage, and when an affected creature hits with a weapon attack, it can deal fire damage instead of the weapon's normal damage type.
In addition, you and affected creatures in the aura can add your Charisma modifier (minimum of +1) to Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) and Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks.

subclassFeature.name: Fervent Inquisitor
entries: Whenever a creature damages you or one of your allies within 30 feet of you that you can see, you can use your reaction to gain advantage on your next attack roll against the creature that dealt the damage. Additionally, whenever you deal fire or radiant damage to a creature with half its hit points or fewer, you become aware of any lies the creature has willingly and knowingly spoken to you in the past 24 hours.

subclassFeature.name: Fire and Brimstone
entries: As a bonus action, you embody cleansing flame and gain the benefits below for 10 minutes or until you end them (no action required). Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest. You can also restore your use of it by expending a 5th-level spell slot (no action required).

items: You gain immunity to fire damage.
Lashes of divine flame increase your reach by 10 feet, and your melee attacks ignore half and {@quickref Cover||3||three-quarters cover}.

When you hit a creature with an opportunity attack, or when a hostile creature ends its turn within your reach, it must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone} and have its speed reduced to 0 until the start of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Grim Harbinger
entries: {@i Seal Fate as an Omen of Doom}

Grim harbingers wander places touched by death, serving as both a watcher of the dead and the herald of doom for those whose lives are running out. At their side is a guardian spirit and omen of death known as a grim, a constant companion that aids in performing their shared, grave duty.

subclassFeature.name: Grim Harbinger Spells
entries: You learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Grim Harbinger Spells table. Each spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

entries.caption: Grim Harbinger Spells
rows: 3rd
{@spell Bane|PHB}
5th
{@spell Hold Person|PHB}
9th
{@spell Fear|PHB}
13th
{@spell Intrusive Despair|CrookedMoon14}
17th
{@spell Dream|PHB}

subclassFeature.name: Omen of Doom
entries: As a bonus action, you target a creature you can see within 90 feet of you and magically seal its doom for 1 hour. Once per turn when you hit the doomed target with an attack, it takes an extra {@damage 1d6} necrotic damage.

In addition, a ghostly creature called the {@creature Grim|CrookedMoon24} appears in an unoccupied space within 30 feet of the target. Grims most often appear as black, spectral hounds, but you can choose an appearance appropriate to its stat block.
The grim is friendly to you and your allies, and it obeys your commands. It vanishes if you die, when the doomed creature dies, when it is reduced to 0 hit points, or when you use this feature again.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest. You can also expend a spell slot to restore an expended use (no action required).

entries.name: The Grim in Combat
entries: In combat, the grim acts during your turn. It can move and use its reaction on its own, but the only action it takes is the {@action Dodge} action unless you take a bonus action to command it to take an action in its stat block or some other action. You can also command it as part of the bonus action you take to use Omen of Doom, or you can sacrifice one of your attacks when you take the {@action Attack} action to command the grim to take the Ominous Rend action. If you are {@condition incapacitated}, the grim acts on its own and is not limited to the {@action Dodge} action.

subclassFeature.name: Harbinger of Doom
entries: Your control over doom grows stronger, granting the following benefits.

entries.name: Graveyard Hunter
entries: The {@creature Grim|CrookedMoon24|Grim's} Ominous Rend action deals an extra {@damage 1d6} necrotic damage on a hit.

entries.name: Mortal Reminder
entries: When you deal damage to a creature doomed by your {@subclassFeature Omen of Doom|Ranger|PHB|Grim Harbinger|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14}, you can change the damage type to necrotic.

entries.name: Mounting Dread
entries: Necrotic damage dealt by you or the Grim ignores resistance.

subclassFeature.name: Grave Bond
entries: You draw deeper strength from the grave. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Ghastly Hound
entries: The Grim gains resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

entries.name: Grave Fortitude
entries: You gain resistance to necrotic damage.

entries.name: Inescapable Fate
entries: When the target of your {@subclassFeature Omen of Doom|Ranger|PHB|Grim Harbinger|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14} succeeds on a saving throw, you can use your reaction to force it to reroll the save with disadvantage and use the new roll. Once you cause a save to fail with this benefit, you can't use it again until the current {@subclassFeature Omen of Doom|Ranger|PHB|Grim Harbinger|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14} ends.

subclassFeature.name: Sealed Fate
entries: The strength of your {@subclassFeature Omen of Doom|Ranger|PHB|Grim Harbinger|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14} reaches its peak, granting the following benefits while it is active.

entries.name: Jaws of Doom
entries: The {@creature Grim|CrookedMoon24|Grim's} Ominous Rend action deals an extra {@damage 1d6} necrotic damage (for a total of {@damage 2d6} extra damage).

entries.name: Marked for Death
entries: When you use {@subclassFeature Omen of Doom|Ranger|PHB|Grim Harbinger|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14}, you can force the target to make a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, until the current {@subclassFeature Omen of Doom|Ranger|PHB|Grim Harbinger|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14} ends, the target has vulnerability to damage dealt by the grim and to the extra damage you deal with {@subclassFeature Omen of Doom|Ranger|PHB|Grim Harbinger|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14}. Once you use this benefit, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest. You can also restore your use of it by expending a spell slot of 4th level or higher (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Sinner
entries: {@i Deal in Vice to Jinx Foes and Bend Luck}

Vice clings to Sinners like a second skin—cheating, drunkenness, and games of chance are their bread and blood. A scoundrel by nature, sin calls their name, and when whispers of malefic powers reach their ears, they listen. Those powers offer more than temptation; they grant the tools to deceive, steal, and even kill with a precision these rogues never dreamed of.

Perhaps it begins with a meeting in a seedy saloon, a ritual under desert skies, or a cursed temple found deep in the jungle. No matter the road, the end is always the same: Jinxcraft. Through hexes, curses, and foul magic, Sinners cast aside judgment and righteousness. The laws of man and gods are nothing to them. Only the cold comfort of the path of sin remains.
Sinners wield their Jinxcraft through a wide variety of jinxed items that serve as magical weapons. The Jinx Weapon Forms table offers suggestions for how your jinx weapon might appear.

entries.caption: Jinx Weapon Forms
rows: A wooden, glyph-covered talisman carved into the shape of a pistol that fires magenta blasts
A pair of bone dice that shoot ghastly green bursts of jinxcraft from their pips
Enchanted playing cards that can be thrown with explosive magical power
A lucky coin that launches toward foes when flipped and always returns

subclassFeature.name: Hex Slinger
entries: When you deal damage to a creature with your Sneak Attack, you can unleash the power of your Jinxcraft. When you roll your Sneak Attack dice, designate two of the dice before the roll (such as rolling them separately or using different colored dice). The total rolled on these dice determines the effect of your Jinxcraft as noted on the Hex Slinger Jinxes table. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a short rest.

entries.caption: Hex Slinger Jinxes
rows: {@b Snake Eyes.} On the target's next turn, it can only do one of the following: move or take an action or a {@variantrule Bonus Action|PHB}. If it targets you or your allies with an attack on that turn, it takes 2d6 Psychic damage.

{@b The Nightmare.} The target has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn, and it must immediately take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to move as far as it can away from you, up to its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.

{@b Whiskey Bottle.} The target drops anything it's holding. Until the end of its next turn, when the target picks up an item, it must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or drop the item immediately.
{@b Cheap Shot.} Until the end of its next turn, the target's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is halved, and for that duration, attack rolls against it have {@variantrule Advantage|PHB}.
{@b Withered Arm.} Until the end of its next turn, the target has {@variantrule Disadvantage} on {@variantrule D20 Test|PHB|D20 Tests} that rely on Strength.
{@b Bad Luck.} Until the end of its next turn, when the target makes an attack roll or a saving throw, it subtracts {@dice 1d6} from the total.

{@b Dead Man.} If the next attack roll you make before the end of your next turn misses, it hits instead. If that first attack roll hits, the attack is automatically a {@variantrule Critical Hit|PHB}. If you roll a 20 on the d20, roll the attack's damage dice three times instead of twice.

subclassFeature.name: Get Jinxed
entries: You have learned the secret art of Jinxcrafting—drawing magical power from the dark deeds and deals of sin. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Cards and Bones
entries: You gain proficiency with two gaming sets of your choice (playing cards and dice recommended).

entries.name: Jinx Weapon
entries: As a 1-hour ritual using a {@item gaming set|PHB}, you magically create a jinx weapon that channels your Jinxcraft. This weapon takes the form of a pistol or a {@item gaming set|PHB}. For you, the jinx weapon is a simple ranged weapon with a normal range of 30 feet and a long range of 90 feet, and it deals {@damage 1d8} force damage on a hit. As a {@item gaming set|PHB}, you throw cards, dice, or other {@item gaming set|PHB} pieces, or you use them to unleash bolts of hex magic. Alternatively, you can imbue Jinxcraft into a simple or martial weapon you have proficiency with, turning it into your jinx weapon. The infused jinx weapon deals force damage instead of its normal type. If you create a second jinx weapon, the first vanishes or its Jinxcraft ends.

entries.name: Parlor Trick
entries: You learn one of the following cantrips of your choice: {@spell Dancing Lights|PHB}, {@spell Mage Hand|PHB}, {@spell Minor Illusion|PHB}, {@spell Mysterious Presence|CrookedMoon24}, or {@spell Prestidigitation|PHB}. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for it.

subclassFeature.name: Borrowed Luck
entries: When you use {@subclassFeature Hex Slinger|Rogue|PHB|Sinner|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14}, you siphon away a sliver of the target's luck. You gain inspiration if you don't already have it. If you do have it, you can expend your inspiration instead of expending a use of {@subclassFeature Hex Slinger|Rogue|PHB|Sinner|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14}.

subclassFeature.name: Pick Your Poison
entries: When you use {@subclassFeature Hex Slinger|Rogue|PHB|Sinner|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14}, you can roll the designated Sneak Attack dice twice and choose which total to use.

If the roll you choose is the same number on both dice, the target takes psychic damage equal to half your rogue level. If the roll you choose is a 2 or a 12, you don't expend that use of {@subclassFeature Hex Slinger|Rogue|PHB|Sinner|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14}.

subclassFeature.name: The Other Side
entries: You can call on your otherworldly friends in low places to change the odds of anything you do in your favor. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Crossroads Devilry
entries: When you miss with an attack roll or fail a saving throw, you can expend and roll any number of your Sneak Attack dice (choose the number before you roll) and add the total rolled to the attack or save, potentially turning a miss into a hit or failure into success. Expended dice return after you next use your Sneak Attack.

entries.name: Lady Luck's Smiling
entries: When a creature hits you with an attack roll, you can expend and roll any number of your Sneak Attack dice (choose the number before you roll) and add the total rolled to your AC against that attack, potentially causing the attack to miss. Expended dice return after you next use your Sneak Attack.

subclassFeature.name: Crimson Dynasty
entries: {@i Control the Vital Power of Your Lifeblood}

Crimson Sorcerers harness the ancient magic of blood and life essence. They twist and guide the flow of this quintessential energy as a hunger grows deep within them. They manipulate their power to infuse the vitality of others, or they can rip it away and steal it for themselves.

Crimson Dynasty can be acquired in a variety of ways. Some with this power were born with it. Others were infused with it through a dark ritual or grim event. There are those who discover it through lost secrets.
Consult the Crimson Origins table for a possible origin of your power.

There are a variety of ways you might have received the ability to harness your Crimson Dynasty to manipulate vitality and life essence. The Crimson Origins table offers suggestions of where your power comes from.

entries.caption: Crimson Origins
rows: One of your parents was a vampire. Though you aren't one yourself, you inherited their hunger, and it drives your magic.
You studied blood rites at a monastery that infused your own blood with power.
You survived a vampire's bite, though it left you forever changed and awakened your sorcery.
Your family suffers under a generational curse that has reared its head with you, driving you to drain vital energy.
You studied the secrets of life and death, perhaps to save yourself or a loved one. In so doing, you unlocked the crimson power in your blood.
You died, and a cunning entity offered you a second chance at life. You accepted and awoke with Crimson Dynasty coursing through your veins.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Well
entries: You hold a reserve of vital energy called your Blood Well, which you can use to empower your magic and fuel other powers from this subclass. When you deal damage or restore hit points to a creature, you can expend your Blood Well to add {@dice 1d8} to the total for one target.
You regain your expended Blood Well when you finish a long rest or when a creature takes 10 or more necrotic damage from you at one time.

subclassFeature.name: Crimson Spells
entries: You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Crimson Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be a necromancy or a transmutation spell from the sorcerer, warlock, or wizard spell list.

entries.caption: Crimson Spells
rows: 1st
{@spell Blood Bolt|CrookedMoon14}, {@spell Cure Wounds|PHB}, {@spell Inflict Wounds|PHB}
3rd
{@spell Aid|PHB}, {@spell Blood Sacrifice|CrookedMoon14}
5th
{@spell Crimson Harvest|CrookedMoon14}, {@spell Vampiric Touch|PHB}
7th
{@spell Death Ward|PHB}, {@spell Sacrificial Siphon|CrookedMoon14}
9th
{@spell Field of Reaping|CrookedMoon14}, {@spell Mass Cure Wounds|PHB}

subclassFeature.name: Pool of Blood
entries: As a bonus action, you can expend your {@subclassFeature Blood Well|Sorcerer|PHB|Crimson|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14}  to magically dissolve into a pool of blood, along with everything you're wearing or carrying, for 1 hour. The transformation ends early if you drop to 0 hit points or if you choose to end it (no action required).
While you are a pool of blood, you use your game statistics with the following changes.

items: Your walking speed becomes 10 feet.
You gain climbing and swimming speeds equal to your walking speed, and you can climb difficult surfaces, including along ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.
You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.
You have immunity to the {@condition prone} condition.
You have advantage on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws.
You can pass through small holes, narrow openings, and even mere cracks.
You can enter and occupy the space of another creature.
You can't drop, use, or otherwise interact with anything you were carrying or holding.
You can't talk, manipulate objects, attack, or cast spells.

subclassFeature.name: Scarlet Vigor
entries: You have resistance to necrotic damage. In addition, when you finish a short rest, you can expend your {@subclassFeature Blood Well|Sorcerer|PHB|Crimson|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14} to reduce your level of {@condition exhaustion}, if any, by 1.

subclassFeature.name: Vital Siphoning
entries: You can feed on your own life essence to fuel your magic. As a bonus action, you can expend a Hit Die and choose one of the following benefits.

entries.name: Blood Boil
entries: You regain the use of your {@subclassFeature Blood Well|Sorcerer|PHB|Crimson|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14}.

entries.name: Crimson Pulse
entries: Expend your {@subclassFeature Blood Well|Sorcerer|PHB|Crimson|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14} to make the next Metamagic option you use this turn cost no sorcery point.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Feast
entries: Your hunger for vital essence is unquenchable. As an action, you can unleash tendrils of blood that lash any creatures of your choice within 30 feet of you. A target must make a Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 5d8} necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If your {@subclassFeature Blood Well|Sorcerer|PHB|Crimson|CrookedMoon14|3|CrookedMoon14} is already expended when you use this action, the targets have disadvantage on the saving throw. If at least one creature takes damage from Sanguine Feast, you regain a number of hit points equal to the damage roll.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest, unless you spend 5 sorcery points to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: The Great Fool
entries: {@i Laugh in the Face of Danger with Foolish Antics}

What horrors and sorrows can't be remedied by maniacal laughter? Warlocks that have made a pact with the Great Fool draw their enigmatic power from a powerful, otherworldly being of jolly revelry, whose twisted sense of humor is lost on mortal understanding. They are a mocking mirror to bring low the arrogant and mighty, though the Great Fool's ultimate designs are often nonsensical and incomprehensible.

Many Warlocks of the Great Fool adopt a signature aesthetic and performance style that best represents their folly. The Foolish Personas table offers archetypes of fools with suggestions for corresponding outfits and routines.

entries.caption: Foolish Personas
rows: {@b The Harlequin.} An elegant outfit of diamond motley with a painted mask—performs dances, gives eloquent speeches, and plays tricks
{@b The Jester.} A two-toned, checkered motley outfit with cap and bells—favors feats of acrobatics, tumbling, and juggling
{@b The Joker.} A vibrant, colorful suit with wild hair and bowler hat—favors silly jokes, slapstick comedy, and clumsy self-deprecation
{@b The Mime.} A striped, black-and-white shirt with a flat cap and red suspenders—pantomimes comical scenarios without speaking
{@b The Sad Clown.} A monochromatic, one-piece outfit with pointed hat and puffball buttons—utilizes melodramatic melancholy and song
{@b The Tramp.} A patch-covered coat, tattered scarf, scuffed shoes, and cigar—leverages sardonic wit, insults, and mocking observations

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: You learn the {@spell Vicious Mockery} cantrip, and The Great Fool lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

entries.caption: Great Fool Expanded Spells
rows: 1st
{@spell Disguise Self|PHB}, {@spell Tasha's Hideous Laughter|PHB}, {@spell Vicious Mockery|PHB}
3rd
{@spell Rope Trick|PHB}, {@spell Spiritual Weapon|PHB}
5th
{@spell Blink|PHB}, {@spell Stinking Cloud|PHB}
7th
{@spell Phantasmal Killer|PHB}, {@spell Puppet Master|CrookedMoon14}
9th
{@spell Bigby's Hand|PHB}, {@spell Mislead|PHB}

subclassFeature.name: Killing Joke
entries: You see the humor in everything—especially in the end of things. When a creature you can see within 60 feet of you takes damage or fails a saving throw, you can use your reaction to cast {@spell Vicious Mockery} on that creature. You can use this reaction a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once). You regain one expended use when you finish a short rest, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Jester's Japes
entries: By calling down an aspect of the Great Fool, you can curse your foes. As an action, you target a creature you can see within 60 feet of you and force it to succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC or suffer one of the following curses (your choice).

entries.name: Flower Spurt
entries: You spray a strange liquid at the creature's eyes, causing it to be {@condition blinded}.

entries.name: Clown Shoes
entries: The creature's feet or similar appendages grow to awkwardly exaggerated proportions. The creature's speed is halved, and it has disadvantage on ability checks and saving throws that rely on Dexterity.

entries.name: Honk Honk
entries: The creature emits sounds, such as honks, chimes, or squeaks, that are audible out to 100 feet with every movement, no matter how slight. The creature can't hide and can't benefit from the {@condition invisible} condition.

entries.name: Jolly Arms
entries: Any weapon or unarmed strike the creature attacks with, including natural weapons such as fangs and claws, takes on a comical appearance as if it were made of wood, stuffed cloth, or balloons.
The target deals half damage with weapon attacks and unarmed strikes.
The curse lasts for 1 minute. The creature repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the curse on a success.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Mocking Banter
entries: Your witty and insulting japes become biting to the point of needling your foes' very psyche. When a creature damages you, you can use your reaction to force the creature to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature takes psychic damage equal to the triggering damage you took, or half as much damage on a successful one.
Once you use this reaction, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Send in the Clowns
entries: You can call upon the laughing, jeering spirits of the followers of the Great Fool to strike down your foes. As a an action, you magically summon three ghostly fools. The fools are translucent and intangible, and they resemble clowns, jesters, or similar entertainers. Make up to three melee spell attacks against creatures within 60 feet of you. On a hit, a target takes {@damage 2d10} psychic damage and is {@condition frightened} of the fools until the end of its next turn, or the target is knocked {@condition prone} (your choice). You can use your action on subsequent turns to repeat the attacks.
The fools remain for 1 minute or until you are {@condition incapacitated} or die. Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Occultism
entries: {@i Seek Beyond the Stars for Forbidden Knowledge}

Wizardry urges the relentless pursuit of knowledge that pushes every boundary in search of greater power and understanding, but some boundaries are never meant to be crossed. Occultisms care not for these limitations, peering behind cosmic veils, devouring forbidden secrets, and pushing their understanding of spellcraft until reality itself tears open.
